reasoning: Crucial because the paper’s optimism about “long views win” vs early lock-in is a central strategic fork: if lock-in is fast, prioritize urgent governance/anti-threat work; if slow, prioritize compounding/institutional/pluralism approaches. Highly paper-specific (directly targets the paper’s conditional claim that selection/asymmetric growth may not have time before persistent decisions), though similar lock-in questions arise in adjacent longtermist work. Tractability is moderate: we can make progress via operationalizing ‘lock-in’ into specific irreversibility mechanisms (AI takeoff/constitutional entrenchment/space expansion patterns), scenario modeling, and identifying reversible vs irreversible commitments—but definitive timelines are inherently speculative and sensitive to unknowns about TAI pathways. Clarity is decent but not perfect because “most-important decisions” and “effectively locked in” need sharper definitions/metrics (e.g., what counts as reversible, who can reverse, at what cost). Decision hook is excellent and explicitly stated. Little dead weight: most text either pins the anchor, defines the flip, or suggests a research approach.
title: Lock-in timing vs patient value accumulation windows
